page.title: 06Maltby Colliery
page.content: Maltby colliery is situated 3km east of the town. It was sunk in 1908 to mine the famous Barnsley seam. The pit has now been deepened to 900m to reach the Swallowood seam. Today 1600 miners produce 1 million tonnes p.a.,with further expansion planned. A new shaft is being sunk to the deeper Haigh Moor and Lidgett seams, guaranteeing the future of the colliery into the 21st century. Outlets for coal include coke ovens,thermal power stations and domestic use. Production was halted during the miners' strike of 1984/5 but has now been resumed. The new giant winding tower has joined the spoil heap at the pit head,forming twin land marks symbolising Maltby's dependence on coal and the miners with their working mens clubs and galas contribute a distinctive character to the life of the neighbourhood.
